That is, I go back home every summer.
And I've been lucky I've had the privilege of a great education.
After St. Lawrence, I went to Georgetown University School of Foreign Service.
I teach at the Potomac School as good as it gets, well, a great school.

What's the concern and the information coming out of your students and the people who work in your school there in Kenya in the slum of Kibera?
Well, we have mixed news.
The very good news is in all the violence that has turned most of Kibera into what looks like a war zone, there are spots have remain undamaged.
And the Red Rose School has not been touched.
We have a caretaker, who lives in a room at the school and the school has not been touched.
So we have concern, on the other hand, for the families and the kids who we have been helping.

We don't know where they are, it's very hard to track them, the cell phones are off and, you know, these people have lost everything they had and the need is going to be much greater next week when the kids start coming back to school.
Do you think the school wasn't touched because of luck, because of respect for the school, or because maybe it wasn't a clear symbol of one tribe or another?
Yeah, it wasn't a clear symbol of one tribe or another.
The people who work at the school are from all different ethnic communities, and the children who go to the school from all ethnic - different ethnic communities.
So if when you are growing up, if you just identified yourself as a slum kid and not so much a Luo, not so much a Kikuyu.
How come as - after this presidential result was thrown into chaos, how come people quickly reverted to those types or maybe we're misunderstanding it from thousands of miles away?
I think there's misunderstanding.
The violence in Nairobi where I grew up, for instance in Kibera, there is about 700,000 people to a million people.
The people fighting out on the streets wrecking havoc, looting, I would say, are 10,000 people or less, you know.
So you have people who are neighbors from one ethnic community to the next who are actually not attacking each other.
But there's a lot of young people who are unemployed and who feel their only say in Kenya is to vote and to have a chance in the democracy.
And they feel they cheated, and their leaders have not given them good guidance and they have gone out to riot and to loot and to rape.
And unfortunately, that's how it's happened.
So the people attacking other people, it won't be my neighbors, you know.
None of the neighbors who are living from any different ethnic communities would dare to attack my family, and my family would never attack their neighbors who have lived there all these years.
